- 2-3 green chilies (sliced)
- 2 medium tomatoes (chopped)
-  tsp turmeric powder
- Salt to taste
- Oil (for cooking) 1. Roast the Besan: In a pan, dry roast besan on low heat until golden and set aside.
2. Cook the Vegetables: In the same pan, heat oil and saut sliced green chilies and chopped tomatoes until soft.
3. Combine: Add the roasted besan to the pan along with salt and turmeric powder. Mix well and cook for a few more minutes until heated through.
4. Serve: Serve hot as a side dish.
8. Tomato-Besan Porridge - 1 cup besan (gram flour)
- 2 medium tomatoes (chopped)
- 2-3 green chilies (chopped)
- Salt to taste
- Water (as needed) 1. Prepare the Porridge: In a pot, mix besan with enough water to form a smooth paste. Add chopped tomatoes, green chilies, and salt.
2. Cook: Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly to avoid lumps. Cook until the porridge thickens to your desired consistency, adding more water if needed.
3. Serve: Serve warm for a comforting meal.
9. Besan and Tomato Dosa - 1 cup besan (gram flour)
- 1 cup rice flour
- 2-3 medium tomatoes (chopped)
- 2-3 green chilies (chopped)
- Salt to taste
- Water (for batter)
- Oil (for cooking) 1. Prepare the Batter: In a bowl, combine besan, rice flour, chopped tomatoes, green chilies, and salt. Gradually add water to form a smooth batter.
2. Cook the Dosas: Heat a non-stick skillet and pour a ladle of batter, spreading it into a thin circle. Cook until the edges lift, then flip and cook the other side until golden brown.<br

column2: . Besan Pakoras
column3:
1. Prepare the Batter: In a mixing bowl, combine besan, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Gradually add water to form a thick batter. Add chopped green chilies and sliced tomatoes, mixing well.
2. Fry the Pakoras: Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Once hot, drop spoonfuls of the batter into the oil. Fry in batches to avoid overcrowding. Fry until golden brown and crispy, about 4-5 minutes.
3. Serve: Drain on paper towels and serve hot with mint or tamarind chutney.
5. Besan Bhurji - 1 cup besan (gram flour)
- 2 medium tomatoes (chopped)
- 2-3 green chilies (chopped)
-  tsp turmeric powder
-  tsp cumin seeds
- Salt to taste
- 1-2 tbsp oil
- Fresh coriander (for garnish) 1. Cook the Vegetables: In a pan, heat oil and add cumin seeds. Once they crackle, add chopped tomatoes and green chilies. Cook until the tomatoes are soft.
2. Add Besan: Add besan and turmeric powder to the pan. Stir well and cook for a few minutes until the besan is well mixed with the tomatoes.
3. Serve: Garnish with fresh coriander and serve hot with bread or rice.
6. Tomato and Besan Curry - 2 cups chopped tomatoes
-  cup besan (gram flour)
- 2-3 green chilies (chopped)
-  tsp turmeric powder
- 1 tsp cumin seeds
- Salt to taste
- Water (as needed)
- Oil (for cooking) 1. Cook the Tomatoes: In a pot, heat oil and add cumin seeds. Once they crackle, add chopped tomatoes and green chilies. Cook until the tomatoes break down.
2. Add Besan: In a separate bowl, mix besan with a little water to form a slurry. Add this paste to the pot along with salt and turmeric powder.
3. Simmer: Stir well and add enough water to reach your desired consistency. Let it simmer for about 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally.
4. Serve: Serve hot with rice or roti.
7. Besan Stir-fry - 1 cup besan (gram flour)
- 2-3 green chilies (sliced)
- 2 medium tomatoes (chopped)
-  tsp turmeric powder
- Salt to taste
- Oil (for cooking) 1. Roast the Besan: In a pan, dry roast besan on low heat until golden and set aside.
2. Cook the Vegetables: In the same pan, heat oil and saut sliced green chilies and chopped tomatoes until soft.
3. Combine: Add the roasted besan to the pan along with salt and turmeric powder. Mix well and cook for a few more minutes until heated through.
4. Serve: Serve hot as a side dish.
8. Tomato-Besan Porridge - 1 cup besan (gram flour)
- 2 medium tomatoes (chopped)
- 2-3 green chilies (chopped)
- Salt to taste
- Water (as needed) 1. Prepare the Porridge: In a pot, mix besan with enough water to form a smooth paste. Add chopped tomatoes, green chilies, and salt.
2. Cook: Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly to avoid lumps. Cook until the porridge thickens to your desired consistency, adding more water if needed.
3. Serve: Serve warm for a comforting meal.
9. Besan and Tomato Dosa - 1 cup besan (gram flour)
- 1 cup rice flour
- 2-3 medium tomatoes (chopped)
- 2-3 green chilies (chopped)
- Salt to taste
- Water (for batter)
- Oil (for cooking) 1. Prepare the Batter: In a bowl, combine besan, rice flour, chopped tomatoes, green chilies, and salt. Gradually add water to form a smooth batter.
2. Cook the Dosas: Heat a non-stick skillet and pour a ladle of batter, spreading it into a thin circle. Cook until the edges lift, then flip and cook the other side until golden brown.<br

column2: Tomato and Besan Curry Recipe
column3:
1. Cook the Tomatoes: In a pot, heat oil and add cumin seeds. Once they crackle, add chopped tomatoes and green chilies. Cook until the tomatoes break down.
2. Add Besan: In a separate bowl, mix besan with a little water to form a slurry. Add this paste to the pot along with salt and turmeric powder.
3. Simmer: Stir well and add enough water to reach your desired consistency. Let it simmer for about 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally.
4. Serve: Serve hot with rice or roti.

column2: Besan and Tomato Dosa
column3:
1. Prepare the Batter: In a bowl, combine besan, rice flour, chopped tomatoes, green chilies, and salt. Gradually add water to form a smooth batter.
2. Cook the Dosas: Heat a non-stick skillet and pour a ladle of batter, spreading it into a thin circle. Cook until the edges lift, then flip and cook the other side until golden brown.<br

column2: Rabri Recipe
column3:
1. Boil milk in a wide pan and simmer on low heat, stirring continuously.
2. As the cream forms on the surface, push it to the sides of the pan.
3. Add sugar and cardamom powder, and continue reducing until thick.
4. Serve chilled.

column2: Sweetened Condensed Milk Recipe
column3:
1. Heat milk in a pan and bring it to a boil.
2. Add sugar and simmer the milk on low heat, stirring continuously to avoid burning.
3. Continue to reduce the milk until it becomes thick and creamy.
4. Use in desserts or serve as is.

column2: Milk Cake Recipe
column3:
1. Boil milk and reduce it to half.
2. Add lemon juice to curdle the milk slightly.
3. Add sugar and cook until it thickens into a dough-like consistency.
4. Set in a greased tray, cool, and cut into pieces before serving.

column2: Barfi (Milk Fudge) Recipe
column3:
1. Boil milk and reduce it to half.
2. Add sugar and ghee, stirring continuously until it thickens.
3. Cook until it reaches a dough-like consistency.
4. Spread on a greased tray, cool, and cut into squares to serve.

column2: Peda (Milk Sweet)
column3:
1. Boil milk in a heavy-bottomed pan and reduce it to a thick consistency.
2. Add sugar and cardamom powder, and continue cooking until it becomes thick like dough.
3. Shape the mixture into small discs (peda) and let them cool.

column2: Milk Halwa (Doodhi Halwa) Recipe
column3:
1. Heat ghee in a pan and add milk.
2. Add sugar and stir until the mixture thickens.
3. Continue cooking until it turns into a thick, grainy halwa.
4. Add cardamom powder and nuts for flavor, and serve warm.

column2: 1. Scrambled Eggs
column3: To make scrambled eggs, whisk the eggs in a bowl and cook them in a hot pan with some butter or oil. Stir them gently while cooking to get soft, fluffy pieces. You can add salt, pepper, and other spices or herbs to taste. It's a quick and simple breakfast.

column2: Omelette
column3: An omelette is made by beating eggs and pouring them into a hot pan to cook. You can add fillings like cheese, chopped vegetables, or cooked meat. Once the eggs are firm, fold them in half. Omelettes are great for a customizable breakfast or meal.

column2: Boiled Eggs
column3: Boiling eggs is easy. Just place them in boiling water for around 6-10 minutes, depending on whether you like a soft or hard yolk. Soft-boiled eggs have a runny center, while hard-boiled eggs are fully cooked inside. They're perfect for snacks, salads, or sandwiches.

column2: Poached Eggs
column3: Poached eggs are made by gently cooking eggs in simmering water. The whites set while the yolks stay runny, making them perfect for serving over toast, salads, or with other breakfast dishes like eggs Benedict.

column2: Frittata
column3: A frittata is like a baked omelette thats packed with ingredients such as vegetables, cheese, and sometimes meats like sausage or bacon. The mixture is cooked slowly on the stove or baked in the oven until firm, making it a hearty dish for breakfast, lunch, or dinner.

column2: Egg Curry Recipe
column3: In egg curry, boiled eggs are simmered in a flavorful, spiced gravy made from onions, tomatoes, and traditional Indian spices like cumin and coriander. Its usually served with rice or bread, making it a filling and flavorful meal.

column2: Chana Masala Recipe
column3: A popular Indian dish where chickpeas are cooked in a spicy gravy made from onions, tomatoes, and a mix of spices like cumin and coriander. Its usually served with rice or flatbread.

column2: Chickpea Salad Recipe
column3: A fresh and healthy salad made by combining boiled chickpeas, diced onions, and chopped tomatoes. Dress it with lemon juice, olive oil, salt, and pepper for a refreshing meal.

column2: Tomato Chickpea Curry Recipe
column3: A comforting curry made by simmering chickpeas in a rich sauce of sauted onions and tomatoes, flavored with spices. Serve it hot with rice or bread for a hearty meal.

column2: Hummus with Tomato and Onion Recipe
column3: A twist on traditional hummus, made by blending cooked chickpeas with garlic, tahini, lemon juice, and adding sauted onions and tomatoes for extra flavor. Serve with pita bread or veggies.

column2: Chickpea and Tomato Stew Recipe
column3: A warming stew where chickpeas, chopped onions, and diced tomatoes are cooked together with broth and spices until thick. Serve it with crusty bread for a filling meal.

column2: Tomato and Chickpea Soup Recipe
column3: A hearty soup made by cooking chopped onions, tomatoes, and chickpeas in vegetable broth, seasoned with herbs. Its perfect for a light lunch or dinner, served hot with bread.

column2: Tomato Onion Sabzi Recipe
column3:
Heat oil in a pan and saut chopped onions until soft.
Add chopped tomatoes, green chilies, and cumin seeds. Cook until the tomatoes break down.
Once done, let it cool slightly, then blend the mixture into a smooth paste.
Add salt to taste. This chutney pairs well with dosa or as a side for rice.

column2: Spicy Tomato Soup Recipe
column3:
Saut chopped onions, tomatoes, and green chilies in butter until soft.
Add water, salt, and pepper to taste. Let the mixture simmer until everything is tender.
Blend the soup until smooth and creamy. Serve hot.

column2: Tomato Onion Sabzi Recipe
column3:
Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds. Saut chopped onions and green chilies until golden.
Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric, and salt. Cook until tomatoes become soft and the mixture thickens.
Serve with chapati or rice for a simple, flavorful meal.

column2: Tomato and green Chili Chutney Recipe
column3:
Saut onions, green chilies, and garlic in oil until soft.
Add chopped tomatoes and mustard seeds. Cook until the mixture thickens.
Blend into a smooth chutney. This chutney is great with snacks like samosas or pakoras.

column2: Tomato Green Chili Pickle Recipe
column3:
Mix chopped tomatoes, green chilies, and onions with mustard seeds, vinegar, and salt.
Store the mixture in a jar and let it sit for a day or two to develop flavor. This spicy pickle can be enjoyed with any meal.

column2: Tomato Onion ,Green Chillie Gravy Recipe
column3:
Saut onions, green chilies, garlic, and ginger in oil until fragrant.
Add chopped tomatoes, cumin, and coriander. Cook until the tomatoes break down into a thick gravy.
This gravy can be used as a base for curries or with vegetables like potatoes or paneer.

column2: Urad Dal Khichdi
column3:
Wash the urad dal and rice separately under cold water until the water runs clear. This removes excess starch and impurities.
(Optional) Soak them together in water for about 30 minutes to help them cook faster.
Heat the Ghee or Oil:

In a pot or pressure cooker, heat 1-2 tablespoons of ghee or oil over medium heat.
Add Spices:

Once the ghee or oil is hot, add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds. Allow them to splutter.
Add the slit green chilies and grated ginger. Saut for about a minute until fragrant.
Add Vegetables (Optional):

If youre using vegetables, add the chopped ones at this point. Saut them for a few minutes until they begin to soften.
Combine Dal and Rice:

Drain the soaked dal and rice, and add them to the pot. Stir everything together for about a minute to coat the rice and dal with the spices.
Add Water and Salt:

Pour in 4 cups of water and add salt to taste. Stir well to combine.
Cook:

Pressure Cooker: Close the lid and cook for about 2-3 whistles (approximately 10-15 minutes). Once done, let the pressure release naturally.
Regular Pot: Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for about 20-25 minutes, or until the dal and rice are soft and well combined. Stir occasionally and add more water if necessary.

column2: Dokhla
column3:
Prepare the Batter:

In a mixing bowl, combine besan, ginger paste, chopped green chilies, turmeric powder (if using), salt, and lemon juice.
Gradually add water and mix to form a smooth batter.
Add Eno:

Just before steaming, add the Eno fruit salt to the batter and mix quickly. Youll see it froth up, which helps in making the dhokla fluffy.
Prepare Steamer:

Grease a flat, shallow dish or plate. Pour the batter into the dish, spreading it evenly.
Steam:

Place the dish in a steamer (or a large pot with a steaming rack). Steam for about 15-20 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
Temper:

In a small pan, heat oil and add mustard seeds. Once they splutter, add slit green chilies and curry leaves. Saut for a minute.

column2: Spicy Urad Dal
column3:
Rinse the Dal:

Wash the urad dal under running water until clear. Soak it in water for about 30 minutes (optional).
Cook the Dal:

In a pot, add the soaked dal and 4 cups of water. Cook until the dal is soft, about 20-25 minutes. You can also use a pressure cooker for faster cooking (about 2-3 whistles).
Heat Oil:

In a separate pan, heat oil or ghee over medium heat.
Add Spices:

Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Then add the slit green chilies, chopped onions, garlic, and ginger. Saut until the onions are golden brown.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes soften and the oil separates from the mixture.
Combine:

Add the cooked urad dal to the pan. Stir well to combine. Adjust the consistency by adding water if needed. Simmer for 5-10 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.

column2: Dosa
column3:
Prepare the Batter:

Drain the soaked rice and urad dal. Blend them together in a mixer or grinder, adding water as needed, until you have a smooth batter. You can also add fenugreek seeds for extra flavor.
The batter should be thick but pourable. Transfer it to a large bowl.
Ferment the Batter:

Cover the bowl with a cloth and let it ferment in a warm place for 8-12 hours, or until it doubles in size and shows bubbles.
Cook the Dosa:

Once fermented, stir the batter gently and add salt to taste.
Heat a non-stick or cast-iron skillet over medium heat. Once hot, lightly grease it with oil or ghee.
Pour the Batter:

Pour a ladleful of batter in the center of the skillet. Quickly spread it out in a circular motion to form a thin crepe.
Cook:

Drizzle a little oil or ghee around the edges. Cook until the dosa turns golden brown and crispy, about 2-3 minutes.
Flip the dosa (if desired) and cook for another minute.

column2: Appe
column3:
Prepare the Batter:

If you dont have ready-made idli/dosa batter, you can make it by soaking 1 cup of rice and 1/4 cup of urad dal for 4-6 hours, then grinding them into a smooth batter and fermenting overnight.
Mix Ingredients:

In a bowl, combine the fermented batter with chopped onions, green chilies, grated carrots, coriander leaves, and salt. Mix well.
Heat the Appe Pan:

Place the appe pan on medium heat and add a few drops of oil in each cavity.
Pour the Batter:

Once the oil is hot, pour a spoonful of the batter into each cavity, filling them about 3/4 full.
Cook:

Cover the pan with a lid and cook for about 3-4 minutes. Once the bottom is golden brown, use a skewer or spoon to gently flip the appe over.
Finish Cooking:

Cook for another 2-3 minutes until both sides are golden brown and cooked through.

column2: Urad Dal Tadka
column3:
Rinse and Cook the Dal:

Wash the urad dal under running water until clear. Soak for 30 minutes (optional).
In a pot, add the soaked dal and 4 cups of water. Cook until the dal is soft (about 20-25 minutes). You can also use a pressure cooker (2-3 whistles).
Prepare the Tadka:

In a separate pan, heat oil or ghee over medium heat.
Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Then add slit green chilies, chopped onions, garlic, and ginger. Saut until the onions are golden brown.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes soften and the oil separates.
Combine:

Add the cooked urad dal to the pan and mix well. Adjust the consistency with water if needed. Simmer for 5-10 minutes to let the flavors meld.

column2: Chicken Curry
column3:
Heat Oil:

In a large pot, heat the oil or ghee over medium heat.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until they turn golden brown.
Add Garlic and Ginger:

Stir in the minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes soften and the oil starts to separate.
Add Chicken:

Add the chicken pieces to the pot. Mix well to coat the chicken with the spices. Cook for about 5-7 minutes until the chicken is browned.
Cook the Curry:

Add 1-2 cups of water (adjust for desired consistency) and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat, cover, and simmer for about 25-30 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and tender.
Add Garam Masala:

Once the chicken is cooked, stir in the garam masala and cook for another 5 minutes.

column2: Chicken Tika
column3:
Prepare the Marinade:

In a bowl, combine yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, oil, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, garam masala, salt, and kasuri methi (if using). Mix well.
Marinate the Chicken:

Add the chicken cubes to the marinade. Ensure all pieces are well coated. Cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours (or overnight for best results).
Preheat the Oven or Grill:

Preheat your oven to 200C (about 400F) or prepare a grill.
Skewering:

Thread the marinated chicken onto the skewers. Leave some space between the pieces for even cooking.
Cook the Chicken:

Oven: Place the skewers on a baking tray and bake for 15-20 minutes, turning halfway through, until the chicken is cooked and slightly charred.
Grill: Grill the skewers on medium heat for about 10-15 minutes, turning occasionally, until the chicken is cooked through and has a nice char.

column2: Chicken Rost
column3:
Preheat the Oven:

Preheat your oven to 220C (425F).
Prepare the Chicken:

Pat the chicken dry with paper towels. This helps achieve a crispy skin.
Season the Chicken:

In a bowl, mix olive oil (or melted butter), salt, black pepper, paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, and lemon juice.
Rub this mixture all over the chicken, including under the skin for extra flavor.
Optional  Stuffing:

If desired, you can stuff the cavity with fresh herbs, lemon slices, and garlic cloves for added flavor.
Arrange for Roasting:

Place the chicken in a roasting pan. If using, arrange chopped vegetables around the chicken.
Roast the Chicken:

Roast in the preheated oven for about 1 hour and 15 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 75C (165F) and the juices run clear. Baste the chicken with its own juices halfway through cooking.
Rest:

Once cooked, remove the chicken from the oven and let it rest for about 10-15 minutes before carving. This allows the juices to redistribute.

column2: Chicken lollipop
column3:
Prepare the Chicken:

Take the chicken wings and cut around the bone to loosen the meat. Push the meat down towards the thinner end of the wing to create a lollipop shape.
Marinate:

In a bowl, mix the ginger-garlic paste, soy sauce, red chili powder, black pepper, and salt. Add the chicken lollipops and marinate for at least 30 minutes (or longer for better flavor).
Coat:

After marination, sprinkle cornstarch and all-purpose flour (if using) over the chicken. Toss well to coat evenly. This helps create a crispy texture.
Heat Oil:

In a deep frying pan, heat oil over medium heat. Make sure the oil is hot enough for frying.
Fry the Chicken:

Carefully add the chicken lollipops to the hot oil in batches. Fry until they are golden brown and cooked through, about 5-7 minutes. Remove and drain on paper towels.

column2: Chicken chilli
column3:
Marinate the Chicken:

In a bowl, combine the chicken strips, cornstarch, soy sauce, salt, and pepper. Mix well and let it marinate for at least 30 minutes.
Heat Oil:

In a large pan or wok, heat oil over medium-high heat.
Cook the Chicken:

Add the marinated chicken to the pan and stir-fry until it's cooked through and lightly browned. Remove the chicken from the pan and set aside.
Saut Vegetables:

In the same pan, add a little more oil if needed. Add minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Saut for about a minute until fragrant.
Add sliced onions and bell pepper, cooking until they are slightly tender.
Combine:

Return the cooked chicken to the pan. Add chili sauce, tomato ketchup, and adjust salt and pepper as needed. Stir well to coat everything evenly.
Serve:

Garnish with chopped spring onions. Serve hot with rice or noodles.

column2: chicken manchurian
column3:
Marinate the Chicken:

In a bowl, mix the chicken pieces with cornstarch, all-purpose flour (if using), soy sauce, ginger-garlic paste, salt, and pepper. Let it marinate for at least 30 minutes.
Fry the Chicken:

Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Fry the marinated chicken pieces until they are golden and cooked through. Remove and drain on paper towels.
Prepare the Sauce:

In another pan, heat 2 tablespoons of oil. Add chopped onions and green chilies, sauting until the onions are translucent.
Add ginger-garlic paste and saut for another minute until fragrant.
Add Vegetables:

Stir in the bell peppers and cook for a couple of minutes until slightly tender.
Make the Sauce:

Add soy sauce, tomato ketchup, chili sauce, vinegar, and mix well. Adjust the seasoning with salt and pepper as needed.
Add the cornflour slurry (cornstarch mixed with water) to thicken the sauce, stirring continuously.
Combine:

Add the fried chicken pieces to the sauce and toss well to coat evenly.

column2: Cauliflower Sabji
column3:
In a pan, heat oil over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until they turn golden brown.
Add Garlic and Ginger:

Stir in the minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes soften and the oil separates from the mixture.
Add Cauliflower:

Add the cauliflower florets to the pan and mix well to coat them with the spice mixture.
Cook:

Add a splash of water, cover the pan, and cook for about 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the cauliflower is tender but not mushy.

column2: Cauliflower Steak
column3:
Preheat the Oven:

Preheat your oven to 220C (425F).
Prepare the Cauliflower:

Remove the outer leaves from the cauliflower and trim the stem so it can stand upright.
Carefully slice the cauliflower into 1-inch thick steaks. You should get about 2-3 good-sized steaks from the center; the remaining florets can be used for another dish.
Season the Steaks:

In a bowl, mix olive oil, garlic powder, paprika, cumin, salt, and pepper.
Brush both sides of the cauliflower steaks with the oil mixture.
Roast:

Place the seasoned cauliflower steaks on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
Roast in the preheated oven for about 25-30 minutes, flipping halfway through, until golden brown and tender.

column2: Cauliflower Stir fry
column3:
Heat Oil:

In a large pan or wok, heat the oil over medium-high heat.
Add Aromatics:

Add the minced garlic and grated ginger. Saut for about 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add Vegetables:

Add the cauliflower florets, bell pepper, carrot, and green chilies (if using). Stir-fry for about 5-7 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender but still crisp.
Season:

Add soy sauce, oyster sauce (if using), sesame oil (if using), salt, and pepper. Stir well to combine and cook for another 2-3 minutes.

column2: Rost Cauliflower
column3:
Preheat the Oven:

Preheat your oven to 220C (425F).
Prepare the Cauliflower:

Wash and cut the cauliflower into bite-sized florets. Make sure they are roughly the same size for even roasting.
Season the Cauliflower:

In a large bowl, combine olive oil, garlic powder, paprika, cumin, salt, and pepper. Add the cauliflower florets and toss until they are well coated with the seasoning.
Roast:

Spread the seasoned cauliflower florets in a single layer on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
Roast in the preheated oven for about 25-30 minutes, or until golden brown and tender, tossing halfway through for even cooking.

column2: Cauliflower Curry
column3:
Heat Oil:

In a pan, heat oil over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until they turn golden brown.
Add Garlic and Ginger:

Stir in the minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes soften and the oil starts to separate.
Add Cauliflower:

Add the cauliflower florets and mix well to coat them with the spice mixture.
Cook:

Add about 1 cup of water, cover the pan, and cook for 15-20 minutes, or until the cauliflower is tender.
Finish:

Stir in garam masala and cook for another 2-3 minutes. Adjust the consistency by adding more water if needed.

column2: Masala Cauliflower
column3:
Heat Oil:

In a pan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until they turn golden brown.
Add Garlic and Ginger:

Stir in the minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes soften and the oil begins to separate.
Add Cauliflower:

Add the cauliflower florets and mix well to coat them with the spice mixture.
Cook:

Cover the pan and cook for about 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the cauliflower is tender. You can add a splash of water if needed to prevent sticking.
Finish:

Stir in garam masala and cook for another 2-3 minutes. Adjust the seasoning if necessary.

column2: Chole masala
column3:
Prepare Chickpeas:

If using dried chickpeas, soak them overnight and boil until tender (about 30-40 minutes). If using canned chickpeas, drain and rinse them.
Heat Oil:

In a large pan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until golden brown.
Add Aromatics:

Stir in the minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the tomato puree, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the mixture thickens and the oil separates.
Add Chickpeas:

Add the cooked or canned chickpeas to the pan. Mix well to coat them with the spice mixture.
Simmer:

Add about 1 cup of water to reach your desired consistency. Simmer for 10-15 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld. Stir in garam masala and chole masala (if using).

column2: Chole paratha
column3:
Heat Oil:

In a pan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until golden brown.
Add Aromatics:

Stir in minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the tomato puree, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the mixture thickens and the oil separates.
Add Chickpeas:

Add the boiled or canned chickpeas to the pan. Mix well and simmer for 10-15 minutes. Stir in garam masala and garnish with fresh coriander.
Prepare the Paratha: 6. Make the Dough:

In a mixing bowl, combine whole wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water to form a soft dough. Knead for a few minutes and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
Roll the Parathas:

Divide the dough into equal portions. Roll each portion into a ball, then flatten it slightly. Roll out into a circle (about 6-7 inches in diameter).
Cook the Parathas:

Heat a tava or skillet over medium heat. Cook each paratha for about 1-2 minutes on one side until you see bubbles, then flip it.
Brush with oil or ghee, and cook until both sides are golden brown and crispy.

column2: Chole vada
column3:
Heat Oil:

In a pan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until golden brown.
Add Aromatics:

Stir in minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the tomato puree, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the mixture thickens and the oil separates.
Add Chickpeas:

Add the boiled or canned chickpeas to the pan. Mix well and simmer for 10-15 minutes. Stir in garam masala and garnish with fresh coriander.
Prepare the Vada: 6. Make the Batter:

Drain the soaked urad dal and grind it to a smooth batter with a little water. Mix in chopped green chilies, grated ginger, cumin seeds, and salt.
Heat Oil:

In a deep frying pan, heat oil over medium heat.
Fry the Vadas:

Take a small portion of the batter and flatten it slightly. Carefully drop it into the hot oil. Fry until golden brown and crispy, about 2-3 minutes on each side. Remove and drain on paper towels.
Serve: 9. Assemble:

Serve the chole in a bowl topped with crispy vadas. You can also drizzle some yogurt and tamarind chutney for extra flavor.

column2: Chole bhature
column3:
Heat Oil:

In a pan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until golden brown.
Add Aromatics:

Stir in minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the tomato puree, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the mixture thickens and the oil separates.
Add Chickpeas:

Add the boiled chickpeas to the pan. Mix well and simmer for 10-15 minutes. Stir in garam masala and garnish with fresh coriander.
Prepare the Bhature: 6. Make the Dough:

In a large bowl, mix all-purpose flour, yogurt, baking powder, and salt. Gradually add water to form a soft dough. Knead well and let it rest for at least 30 minutes, covered with a damp cloth.
Roll the Bhature:

Divide the dough into equal portions. Roll each portion into a ball, then flatten it slightly. Roll out into circles (about 6-7 inches in diameter).
Heat Oil:

In a deep frying pan, heat oil over medium heat.
Fry the Bhature:

Carefully drop a rolled bhatura into the hot oil. Fry until it puffs up and turns golden brown, about 1-2 minutes on each side. Remove and drain on paper towels.

column2: Chole sabji
column3:
Heat Oil:

In a pan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Saut Onions:

Add the chopped onions and saut until golden brown.
Add Garlic and Ginger:

Stir in the minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add Tomatoes and Spices:

Add the chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes soften and the oil starts to separate.
Add Chickpeas:

Add the boiled or canned chickpeas to the pan. Mix well to coat the chickpeas with the spice mixture.
Simmer:

Add about 1 cup of water to achieve your desired consistency. Simmer for 10-15 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Finish:

Stir in garam masala and cook for another 2-3 minutes. Adjust seasoning if necessary.

column2: Chole chuntney
column3:
Blend Ingredients:

In a blender or food processor, combine the cooked chickpeas, fresh coriander, green chilies, garlic, roasted cumin seeds, lemon juice, and salt.
Adjust Consistency:

Blend until smooth, adding a little water as needed to achieve your desired consistency. You can make it thicker or thinner based on your preference.
Taste and Adjust:

Taste the chutney and adjust the salt or lemon juice as needed.

column2: Potato Sabji
column3:
Heat Oil: In a pan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds and let them splutter.

Add Potatoes: Add the diced potatoes to the pan. Saut for about 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they start to soften.

Spice It Up: Sprinkle in the turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well to coat the potatoes in the spices.

Add Tomatoes: Add the chopped tomatoes to the pan. Stir everything together. The tomatoes will release moisture, which will help cook the potatoes.

Cover and Cook: Cover the pan with a lid and let it cook for about 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally. If needed, add a little water to prevent sticking.

Check for Doneness: The potatoes should be tender and the tomatoes well-cooked. If they are still firm, cover and cook a bit longer.

Garnish and Serve: Once done, you can garnish with fresh coriander leaves if desired. Serve hot with roti, paratha, or rice.

column2: French Fries
column3:
Prepare the Potatoes:

Peel the potatoes (if desired) and cut them into thin strips (about 1/4 inch thick).
Soak the cut potatoes in cold water for at least 30 minutes. This helps remove excess starch and makes the fries crispier.
Drain and Dry:

After soaking, drain the potatoes and pat them dry with a clean kitchen towel. Make sure they are as dry as possible to avoid oil splatter.
Heat the Oil:

In a deep frying pan or pot, heat oil over medium-high heat. Youll need enough oil to submerge the fries (about 2-3 inches deep). You can test if the oil is hot enough by dropping a small piece of potato in; it should sizzle immediately.
Fry the Potatoes:

Carefully add a handful of the dried potato strips to the hot oil. Dont overcrowd the pan; fry in batches if necessary.
Fry for about 5-7 minutes, or until the fries are golden brown and crispy. Stir occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Drain:

Once done, use a slotted spoon to remove the fries and place them on a plate lined with paper towels to absorb excess oil.
Season:

While they are still hot, sprinkle with salt and any other desired seasonings. Toss to coat evenly.
Serve:

Enjoy your homemade French fries hot, with ketchup or your favorite dipping sauce!

column2: Chip
column3:
Slice the Potatoes:

Wash and peel the potatoes if desired. Use a mandoline slicer or a sharp knife to cut them into thin, even slices (about 1/16 inch thick).
Soak:

Soak the potato slices in cold water for at least 30 minutes to remove excess starch, which helps them become crispier.
Drain and Dry:

Drain the soaked potato slices and pat them dry thoroughly with paper towels. Ensuring they are dry is key to getting crispy chips.
Heat the Oil:

In a deep frying pan or pot, heat oil over medium-high heat. Youll need enough oil to submerge the chips (about 2-3 inches deep).
Fry the Chips:

Once the oil is hot (you can test by dropping a small piece of potato in; it should sizzle), carefully add a handful of the potato slices. Dont overcrowd the pan.
Fry for about 3-5 minutes or until the chips are golden brown and crispy, stirring occasionally.
Drain:

Use a slotted spoon to remove the chips and place them on a plate lined with paper towels to absorb excess oil.
Season:

While still hot, sprinkle with salt and any additional seasonings you like. Toss to coat evenly.
Cool and Serve:

Let the chips cool slightly before serving. Enjoy them fresh, either on their own or with a dip!

column2: Potato Rost
column3:
Prepare the Potatoes:

Peel the potatoes and grate them using a box grater or food processor. If you prefer a coarser texture, you can cut them into small cubes instead.
Rinse and Drain:

Rinse the grated potatoes in cold water to remove excess starch. Drain well and squeeze out as much moisture as possible using a clean kitchen towel or cheesecloth.
Mix Ingredients:

In a bowl, combine the grated potatoes, chopped onion (if using), salt, and pepper. Mix until well combined.
Heat the Pan:

In a large non-stick skillet, heat the oil or butter over medium heat.
Cook the Rsti:

Add the potato mixture to the skillet and flatten it into an even layer. Cook for about 5-7 minutes until the bottom is golden brown and crispy.
Flip:

Carefully flip the rsti using a large plate or spatula. Add a bit more oil if needed, and cook the other side for another 5-7 minutes until golden and crispy.
Serve:

Once cooked, transfer to a plate. You can cut it into wedges or serve it whole. Garnish with fresh herbs if desired.

column2: Potato Fry
column3:
Prepare the Potatoes:

Wash and peel the potatoes if desired. Cut them into thin strips (about 1/4 inch thick) for fries.
Soak:

Soak the cut potatoes in cold water for at least 30 minutes. This helps remove excess starch, making them crispier.
Drain and Dry:

Drain the soaked potatoes and pat them dry with a clean kitchen towel. Make sure theyre as dry as possible.
Heat the Oil:

In a deep frying pan or pot, heat oil over medium-high heat. You need enough oil to cover the fries.
Fry the Potatoes:

Carefully add a handful of the dried potato strips to the hot oil. Fry in batches if necessary to avoid overcrowding.
Fry for about 5-7 minutes, or until golden brown and crispy, stirring occasionally.
Drain:

Use a slotted spoon to remove the fries and place them on a plate lined with paper towels to absorb excess oil.
Season:

While theyre still hot, sprinkle with salt and any additional spices you like. Toss to coat evenly.
Serve:

Enjoy your crispy potato fries hot, with ketchup or your favorite dipping sauce!
